newsitem.title: BELGIUM: MAIN EUROPEAN AIRLINES' PROFITS FALL BACK IN 1996.
newsitem.headline: MAIN EUROPEAN AIRLINES' PROFITS FALL BACK IN 1996.

text.p: Europe's major airlines carried more passengers over longer distances in 1996 but limped in with collective operating losses projected at $90 million, down on 1995's $870 million profit, industry association AEA said on Thursday.

Passenger traffic increases of 6.2 percent and a rise of 7.9 percent in total distance flown were offset by poorer revenue/cost yields and increased fuel prices, the Association of European Airlines said in its 1997 yearbook.
"It seems as if the good 1995 result was only a 'flash in the pan' in a series of many years of losses," AEA secretary general Karl-Heinz Neumeister told a news conference.
Profits in 1995 followed five years of collective losses.
Neumeister said increased passenger numbers failed to help bottom-line profits because airlines had filled surplus seats by offering promotional fares.
"Sometimes airlines get a bit nervous when they see their bookings and additional capacity was certainly filled by attractive offers," he told the launch news conference.
Neumeister nevertheless predicted better results in 1997.
"If one were to make a forecast it would be better. I think when we meet next year, we will probably be in a position to say that 1997 was better than 1996," he said.

Association members include all the major west European flag carriers and some from central Europe and the eastern Mediterranean, meaning combined figures pool results from a very mixed bag of airlines.
The AEA said passenger figures grew most on long-haul routes, up 8.7 percent, compared with 5.1 percent within Europe.
Load factors, the ratio of seats offered to seats filled, showed a similar picture with a record 74.7 percent on long-haul flights in 1996 compared with 61.6 percent within Europe.
The collective fleet of the 26 AEA airlines stood at 1,769 aircraft at the end of last year, virtually static on the year.

The association gave data showing that of the passenger jet aircraft flown by AEA members last year, 47 percent were Boeings , 22 percent McDonnell Douglas , 20 percent Airbus and 11 percent other manufacturers.
Figures for aircraft on order looked better for the European consortium, which held 43 percent of the 301 aircraft on order as opposed to Boeing's 45 percent.
Neumeister refused to be drawn into detailed comment on Thursday's start of a two-day European Commission hearing into the competition effects of Boeing's $14-billion takeover of McDonnell Douglas.
"As long as airlines have the choice of at least two (manufacturers) in each category of aircraft, we would probably not make too much noise," he said. REUTER
